title: Will any disputes over IAEA access to Iranian sites be referred to the Joint Commission before 1 July 2016?
preds:
Official bits on "IAEA Monitoring and Verification in Iran"
https://www.iaea.org/newscenter/focus/iran

Considering that so money is involved in the big Iran-Boeing deal, and who the NY Times top source on Iran happens to be (Tom Pickering), no way  Link here, http://www.algemeiner.com/2016/06/27/scandal-the-new-york-times-favorite-source-on-iran-was-getting-paid-by-boeing/#

Here's the latest.  After the Iran Deal, one would imagine the Obama admin will keep stretching its hand as far as possible: Nuclear Experts: IAEA Needs Access to Parchin to Determine if Iran is Following Nuclear Deal 
http://www.thetower.org/3542-nuclear-experts-iaea-needs-access-to-parchin-to-determine-if-iran-is-following-nuclear-deal/ "...Discovery of uranium particles at the Parchin military complex in Iran underscores the need to grant the agency full access to monitor the site, nuclear experts warned in a brief published Monday. The Obama administration recently acknowledged that the presence of uranium, reported by the IAEA in December, was a sign that nuclear weapons work took place at Parchin."

Believe there are/will be reasons for dispute but no referral to address them,  Alost out of time with this question... http://www.isis-online.org/uploads/isis-reports/documents/Parchin_Post_Implementation_Day_June_20_2016_Final.pdf
Too short a time frame.  Also in the context of the US election, there is no way Obama and the Democrats want to awaken any concerns about the Iran nuclear deal.

Nothing at sight now. Iranian economy has benefited about lifting sanctions. I did not found that many articles about the agreement since january 2016 when the IAEA implented the deal. So nothing disturbing has happened since. I found Interesting scenario play about what will happen if violation by Iran would happen. I leave the 3% for factor X.
According to the general news and GJP consensus with just 1 week to go.

July 1 is coming up and, so far, it seems Iran has adhered to the terms. 
Here's the May status report:
https://www.iaea.org/sites/default/files/16/06/gov2016-23.pdf
According to the general news and GJP consensus with just 2 weeks to go.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Updating forecast to reflect passage of time.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Seems extremely improbable.  From what I have read, the IAEA's very weak idea of an inspection seems very difficult to really obstruct.

Not having done any homework than strictly necessary, I think there are procedural steps such that even if they start the process tomorrow, the official referral can't happen by 01 July.  Anybody more diligent than I have this?
Not giving 0% forecasts anymore when crowd consensus is nearby.
There is very little time left, and no news about the IAEA being discontent.

Iran is just getting hold of their economy. They also have proxy wars going on.
They don't want any economic constraints.
Reducing due to passage of time
Following the expert consensus that 000 is tracking. I also independently calculated less than 10% chance of referral.
lol, with gains in relationship with the west iran is not going to risk, but simply enjoy the ride of replacing saudi's as our allies, russia and israel are more likely to band together
Down from 3%. I haven't seen any indication of potential disputes, though I'd initially expected some to surface and had opened with 45%.
Down to zero. Not much time left.

It looks like Tehran is playing nice with the new nuclear deal.
http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2016/04/02/458655/Iran-IAEA-JCPOA-P51-Amano-Nuclear-Deal/
Reducing for the passage of time.
Reducing from 5% on 19 February for passage of time.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-russia-iran-arms-idUSKCN0X80MM
Iran starts delivery of first S-300 system to Iran. 
If anyone is interested in overturning the appearently inaccurate scoring decision earlier in the year, please contact the judges.
The 'hawks' are circling and the Iranians will not be foolish enough to  breach this agreement - at least not in the short term
The next meaningful action will be taken by Israel.
Not in USA or Europe interests.

Access to global markets is too important to risk this early in the deal and there has been enough lead time for Iran to remove all traces of anything counter to the deal terms that may exist during the negotiation phase.
Not real disputes...if Iran wants nukes they will wait ten years and renegotiate for a better deal. If they face an existential threat they will go for a bomb ASAP
Taking a small risk on this with 0% call. But don't want to keep revisiting this question as it is unlikely to have much news flow that is relevant enough. All important factors are already known.
the chance referring disputes to the joint commission are getting less likely as July 1 gets closer.
the possibility of disputes arisingis declining. Probablynot
The Iranians are currently pushing on the missiles issue, and will be careful not to push elsewhere until some time later.
If no one is catching fish, maybe there aren't any fish.

Hasn't happened yet. Russia stopped movement of SAM to Iran over concerns raised by Israel; perhaps there is a second diplomatic front that has been opened by the Israelis. However, the US isn't on the inspection team, and of those that are, which are sensitive to Israeli pressure? Very few.

Russia, West Differ on UN Report on Iran's Nuclear Program 
http://www.voanews.com/content/ap-russia-west-differ-on-un-report-on-iran-nuclear-program/3225407.html
They are not going to upset the apple cart, even if it glows in the dark
Down 1% considering the Iranian elections seem reasonably favorable.
Don't think the Iranians will cause trouble after only a few months of lifting of sanctions. If they have any plans it would be more long term.
(no change) One needs to look at the JCPOA, but if memory serves me we are almost out of time for this process to even be invoked since there are a series of steps with time periods built in.
everyone seems to want to make this work

Reducing from 8% last month. Still no indications of any stumbling blocks, or hints from anywhere of unreported nuclear-related sites. A slight possibility remains of questions being raised about ballistic missile sites, as the missiles Iran has been testing are deemed to be capable of carrying nuclear warheads.
Bringing it down 5%, following the crowd.
Down 3% to be more under consensus.
50/50, it is entirely contingent on what the IAEA asks to inspect.

The newer construction sites near Parchin should be inspected, but as these are military they are not part of the deal.  I don't think any of the primary backers of the deal have an interest in discrediting it now while money can be made.  There will be time for recriminations later (see also: N. Korea)

Regretting raising probability on the basis of the treatment of Rezaian's mom and wife. The power players in that incident have no significant influence on how Iran treats the IAEA. There's too much money and power at stake to play those sorts of games against the nuclear inspectors.
Tracking down a bit. Not seeing anything relevant at the moment.
Iran and the US will bend over backwards to make this work, at least in the near term, given the expended political capital.

No obstructive action will happen (if at all) until after the US Presidential elections, in the hope that the Democratic Party can regain power, and using the Iranian deal as an example of their affirmative diplomatic actions.
Affirming forecast. Neither side will want any public disagreement. Disputes will be resolved behind the scenes, unofficially.
I donot see what they could do ?  They need money so they would not do anything that would compromise the inflow of cash.
Highly unlikely that Iran will want to risk provoking the IAEA
The Iranians have shown a strong pattern of cooperation lately.

Fermi: Three things have to happen (all before 1 July). 1) The IAEA has to request access to an area which Iran doesn't want them to see
2) Iran has to make the active judgement to challenge this - resulting in dispute
3) The dispute needs to be referred rather than resolved All this in short timeframe and in a climate where Iran's moderates continue to take a positive approach to western engagement. However, slightly higher than 5% given current climate in region is hugely unpredictable.
Everybody's cooperating so far. There may be hitches on the way but they are unlikely to be referred upwards.
Raising on the basis of the way Iranian authorities treated Jason Rezaian's wife and mother. Dateline 1-18-16 http://www.latimes.com/world/europe/la-fg-jason-rezaian-release-20160118-story.html

Doubtful that Iran will be agressive on pushing nuclear treaty envelope before millions of barrels of stored Iranian oil sold.
Doubtful what action Obama and Kerry would take even assuming it occurred and was discovered.
Rather unlikely given the Iranian's behavior right now, but still possible.
I need to be bolder than the consensus. Given their rapid initial compliance, i don't see an infraction before July 1.
Disputes are very probable, but unlikely to be escalated.
Downward revision based on continued cooperation at this point.

It occurs to me that after Implementation Day, simply referring an access dispute to the JtComm doesn't necessarily void the Big Deal; an accommodation would surely be arrived at.  Somebody might do this just to keep the Iranians on notice--once you give someone your cojones to hold, you should not be surprised at a little squeeze from time to time.  Still seems unlikely in this time frame, though.
No pne wants the deal to appear to have fallen apart that fast so, even if something could be referred, I suspect it won't.  What's the outside view?

they are enjoying a less hostile world public opinion towards them...especially after the assassination of shiite cleric...it would be dumb to ruin that...look how well it's going public relations wise for putin when he showed restraint after turkey downed their jet fighter plane....

Obama will do anything to avoid 
His "Iran " legacy.  Time running out
Iran will seek to avoid any disputes
Yes. The IAEA has still yet to gain access to one of the military sites (Parchin) thought to be involved in the nuclear program.
Adjusting down for passage of time.

With Iran becoming more isolated and the regional threats escalating, increasing probability slightly. Dateline 1-4-16 Bahrain cut ties to Iran on Monday, giving Iranian diplomats 48 hours to leave the country, a day after Saudi Arabia did the same. Saudi Arabia’s full break with its rival came after protesters burned and ransacked part of the Saudi Embassy in Tehran on Saturday in response to Saudi Arabia’s execution on Saturday of Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr, a Shiite cleric who was among the 47 men executed on the same day, on terrorism or terrorism-related charges.

The executions escalated tensions between Sunni Saudi Arabia (and its allies) and Shiite Iran — tensions already unfolding in Syria, Yemen, and across the region. Shortly after Bahrain broke off relations on Monday, Sudan expelled the Iranian ambassador from Khartoum and the United Arab Emirates withdrew its ambassador to Tehran, replacing him with the  chargé d’affaires. Morning Brief: Foreign Policy [fp@foreignpolicy.com]

http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2016/01/01/461610337/as-iran-moves-swiftly-on-nuclear-deal-sanctions-could-go-soon Moderate Iranians want to comply to achieve the benefits of the lifted sanctions before the elections.
In an election year, this is not likely to happen unless Iran makes a big misstep.

Starting at 10%. Summary by NPR of current trajectory on implementation. http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2016/01/01/461610337/as-iran-moves-swiftly-on-nuclear-deal-sanctions-could-go-soon
Will reassess in late January in light of implementation's progress (or lack thereof) and Majles election dynamics. Skeptical in long term, but sense that Iranian regime wants to make this work in near-term for sanctions relief. Also, unlikely the U.S. Administration wants to have one of its "signature" diplomatic initiatives be perceived as unravelling in middle of presidential election season.
No change on assessment. Updating for passage of time.
Still 1/5 scenario. Potential for Hardliners screwup to access denial always exists

The only reason I give any likelihood to this is because I wouldn't be surprised if Israel or Saudi Arabia or the US invent some contrived situation to justify reinstating sanctions.  I wouldn't expect that Iran would be found to have nuclear weapons activity in the end, but I wouldn't be surprised if accusations are made and Iran is accused of violating rules.

Now that the IAEA has indicated  Implentation Day could occur even before the end of January, chances look good that disputes between Iran and the IAEA will be resolved among themselves without escalating to the Joint Commission. Everybody seems to be in a co-operative mood at the moment.

The results of Iran's sanctions de3fying missile test should provide insight into the likelihood of this sort of dispute. Raising probability slightly. Dateline 12-16-15 Iran threatened with new sanctions over missile test; UN panel finds that Tehran violated Security Council resolution by test-firing nuclear-capable missile in October. http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/12/iran-threatened-sanctions-missile-test-151216040250405.html

I feel assured that Iran will object to the IAEA, or any other inspecting agencies, to conduct inspections of SOME of their classified military or nuclear weapons or enrichment facilities. Just my humble opinion.
There is no way Iran doesn't want this deal to go through.
It is very unlikely that this will occur to time constraints and the IAEA wrap up of the investigation of Parchin.

With Iran indicating a strong desire to have the PMD file closed by the time, or when, the IAEA reports this week and France expecting precise answers to the PMD dimension of the nuclear agreement, it is likely and reasonable to expect that any PMD dimensions that have occurred prior to agreements will be discussed by the Governing Board; it is likely that any indications of an unknown nuclear military dimensions will delay the lifting of sanctions even further as well as implementation.  PMD, as has been expected, is the crossroads for this agreement.

Reuters assessment of the current situation & statements from Iranian officials; statement included regarding desire to complete requirements before the February election.  http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/24/us-iran-nuclear-idUSKBN0TD23R20151124#wb2pPjcMTjmDUtm5.97 Current assertions about interpreting the deal:   http://www.businessinsider.com/the-iran-deal-just-hit-a-huge-snag-2015-10

It's party time in Iran now. I strongly doubt that the establishment would let the hard liners take away the punch bowl. Dateline 11-28-15 Iran is pitching 70 oil and natural gas projects valued at $30 billion to foreign investors at a two-day conference in Tehran that started today as the Persian Gulf country prepares for the end of sanctions that have stifled its energy production. All banking and economic sanctions will be lifted by the first week of January,” Amir Hossein Zamaninia, deputy oil minister for international and commerce affairs, said at the event. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-11-28/oil-majors-queue-up-in-iran-with-30-billion-of-projects-in-play  Dateline 11-25-15 Iran expects a deal it reached with world powers in July, under which sanctions will be lifted in return for it scaling down its nuclear program, to be implemented at the start of next year, Iranian nuclear negotiator Abbas Araqchi said on Tuesday. "We expect early January," Araqchi told reporters after meeting the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), which is tasked with verifying whether Iran is keeping its commitments under the deal. Iran is holding parliamentary elections on Feb. 26 and diplomats say Tehran has been working hard to fulfill its commitments under the nuclear deal before that date.
 http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/24/us-iran-nuclear-idUSKBN0TD23R20151124
Maintaining current forecast. No relevant information available to alter current perceptions.
Reducing from 35 on 27 Oct. Partly due to passage of time but more to get a little closer to the consensus.
Lowering forecast for passage of time.

Adjusting downward. I still think that any disputes will be ironed out short of any Joint Commission involvement, and Russian-Allied cooperation against has a residual effect of taking pressure off Iran as primary Middle Eastern malefactor. Not to mention that Iran's armed forces are needed to fight ISIS. Both sides will cooperate in keeping disputes to a minimum, and resolving them quietly.
Whatever is actually happening will be redefined in a way that renders this unnecessary. For the next year or so, it doesn't matter what's true--it only matter what the paperwork says.

Whoa, I have been forecasting based on what "access" means to me, but just realized (a little slow on the old uptake there aren't we?) that based on the Parchin example, there will be a way to keep both the IAEA and Iran happy regarding access. Everyone else will probably grit their metaphorical teeth and hope.

If Russia has ongoing needs to deal with NATO and US and Assad on way out.Iran must act in concert with Russia. Its most reliable ally, Russia. That gets me after Putin  current attempts at rapprochment  less confident. It may well be   Iran complies with the agreement and 6 months is a shortening time horizon.
Iran will go to great lengths to achieve compliance. The problems are more likely further down the road
Going up some until it is clear what the Supreme Leader, et al are willing to accept.
Iran will have to test the agreement.

Given the Reuters report today, Iran has announced through various channels (Parliament and National Security) that dismantlement at Natanz and an additional site, required by the Agreement and verification by IAEA, several problems are noted:  Will Iran continue to dismantle for Arat and Natanz in the near future?  Will the Supreme Leader of the country endorse this decision; or had he already done so but not reported in the media?   Given the closed nature of Iran's political structure, hardliners in the theocracy (both Parliament & other institutional structures) have significant support from the Supreme Leader?  The moderate parliamentary and cabinet forces (such as Prime Minister) only have the Supreme Leader on this question of this particular agreement and largely nothing else.   If the current path is held closer to Implementation day or even after the parliamentary election in February, it is rational to assume that they will not be able to complete the required deadlines.  This situation would also impact the work of the IAEA which is required by the agreement to report on verification requirements of PMD (possible military dimensions) and the dismantlement requirements of two specific nuclear reactors.
Updating with crowd and passage of time.
neglected to put in my percentage before submitting my prior comment

I don't believe Iran will be cooperative, but the IAEA will likely try to avoid escalating issues so quickly  (negotiations will quietly drag on well beyond deadlines, as has been the case with every aspect of the Iran deal so far…….with the possible exception of sanctions relief)

Since Implementation Day will occur prior to this date, it is unlikely that Iran will have place obstacles within its own path before receiving sanctions relief.  IAEA access to sites will mot likely be completed before or prior to mid-year.  Change is forecast to NO.

Unfortunatly. Even the Iranians grant us total clearity, we will not be able to accept that transparity as reasuring. Therefore it's probable there will be serious disputes. It's a lack of western confidence/ trust.
The agreement doesn't seem to have the full support of the Supreme Leader of Iran.  Therefore, I expect it to be violated if not out right cancelled by this date.
Very little chance. Iran will ensure it does not jeaoardize receiving its funds
Main stream media hasn't picked up the HuffPost item, so lowering.
There will be disputes eventually. Before July the IAEA may still be working on the non-controversial sites and inspecting them.

IAEA's initial visit to Parchin went off without a hitch. As mentioned in many other forecasts, Iran will be willing to swallow this pill in order to lift sanctions and get SWIFT access back. Any dispute would be over access to military bases, and IAEA has its hands full with the known civilian sites. The hardliners will make a fuss in order to appease the base, but it seems outside the time scope of this question.
Iran will want to give all appearances of complying with the agreement until such time as they have nuclear weapon capability fully developed.
Iran needs time to restructure internal economy; 1 July 2016 is too soon for open warfare in any case.
Some locations potentially also include other classified operations of the Iranian military and government, so there will be potential conflict there.
Iran is very important potential ally of US among the islamic countries. Probably no complains will be risen as long Iran is on a way of warming relations with the West.
No, diplomacy will have to dry out beforehand.
Iran wants sanctions relief and will most likely cooperate for the near future.
Khamenei isn't making things easier. Still nothing about his health.
Iran wants sanctions relief so wont try much for now.
Iranians will work with the IAEA at the early stages of the implementation of controls and once iran considers that verifications are on autopilot they will start running their own agenda

I think Iran wants to drag their feet, as a general behavior trait. They won't rush into it and will wait for some type of political cover as their reason why it had to be done. I just don't think the conditions I highlight below will get to a tipping point by July 1. 1) Oil prices and demand for oil. If they can make more money by selling oil, their economic isolation would be less stressful...hence less pressure to make a deal with the "Great Satan"   
2) Strength of ISIS and threat to the region. Forcing greater cooperation between them and West.
There must be a dispute-may be chances are even bigger Depends of the other moves on this a rather complicated chess game but among a Masters .

I must say, I would be foolish not to defer in some manner to the Anneinak analysis (below), which is so comprehensive. Setting aside any "scoring" bias and looking at it strictly as an exercise in estimating the likelihood of the outcome, I'm going +10. It is unclear what the weight of item NO/2 was given (I'm not re-doing the math), but I'm looking at that as a key variable keeping my forecast low. Of course contentious parties may still seek to intervene, but the faster Iran moves, the fewer options are available to those parties to do so. Also, perhaps I've missed it being used by others this way, but Anneinak has put the Upvote feature to an innovative formal use in her analysis.

Here's the arguments that I find compelling that I've read here and elsewhere: YES arguments
1) Iran will test the boundaries/limits/process.  see Raisinville Oct 2, 2015 05:17PM and processman Oct 28, 2015 02:12PM
2) Initial IAEA monitoring likely to be assertive and robust. see Steve Hammons  Oct 4, 2015 10:14AM
3) some in Iran might not want the agreement implementation to go smoothly/quickly. see Morrell Oct 4, 2015 09:10PM
4) Iran has blocked access before
5) it seems likely that an access dispute will at some point arise and reach the Joint Commission.
6) A committee of Iran's conservative-dominated parliament gave its support on condition there would be no foreign inspections of military sites and no curbs on developing its missile program. see Anneinak Oct 5, 2015 11:22AM
7) Iranian hardliners will need to be thrown some bones.  See Anneinak Oct 5, 2015 11:22AM
8) Vote in Iran was apparently incredibly contentious.  see Morrell  Oct 14, 2015 08:46AM
9) Iran is pushing the envelope on the issue of missile technology sanctions. see cmeinel Oct 22, 2015 12:01PM
10) Compliance without dispute is weakness. see fifty-sixty Oct 25, 2015 05:34AM
11)  Iran is full of suspicious sites. IAEA probably doesn't want to visit them all, but one is enough. see fifty-sixty Oct 25, 2015 05:34AM NO arguments:
1) the Ayatollah supports the agreement.  see cmeinel Oct 21, 2015 05:13PM
2) Iran will be trying to get the agreement implemented quickly. A dispute could potentially delay implementation, so prior to implementation day Iran may be more likely to reach quick agreements with the IAEA. see Morrell Oct 4, 2015 09:10PM
3) before July?  The most difficult negotiations towards the end seemed to focus on notice and ground rules for inspections, having disputes that rise to this level by this date are the uncertainty, not the seeming inevitability of disputes. see thomas.ivor Oct 25, 2015 10:55AM
4) In addition to the politics, inspectors will need to be sure they are right, because if they get it wrong on the first one and number 2 will be a problem.  see Clinton Oct 5, 2015 05:29AM
5) everyone will be playing nice for a while.  see NickLutz Oct 5, 2015 08:55AM
6) the West will take great pains to keep such a referral from happening, because 1) it can be interpreted as a failure of the West to negotiate the treaty properly (a controversy especially to be avoided in the U.S. during a presidential election) and 2) what if the Joint Commission rules against Iran on an issue, and Iran rejects the ruling, and does what it wants anyway? The sanctions against Iran are supposed to be completely eradicated by the end of 2015. Once the sanctions are rolled back, I think they will be extremely difficult to reimpose and I don't think "snapback" will work in any meaningful fashion. So my thinking is that by the middle of next year, Iran will pretty much be able to dig in its heels on any issue it chooses, and the West will have to mollify Iran. Thus in the event of any dispute, everyone will compromise rather than refer the dispute to the Joint Commission. see rjfmgy Oct 14, 2015 10:28AM
7) both parties have a lot to gain by following the rules and a lot to lose by breaking them. . . in the two years they were talking, Kerry and Zarif talked about what their respective governments would say publicly and what that would really mean in practice. This is a fifteen-year deal. More than half the people now in the various governments will be gone by then. Only the paper and the processes it spawns survives. Kerry knew there were guys like Cotton and Cruz going into this thing. Zarif knew about his equivalents. Each of them had to satisfy the other that the agreement would survive those kinds of attacks, and part of that was teaching each other how to interpret extreme statements from legislators to their constituencies. see Walt Oct 15, 2015 01:14PM
8) All parties currently in position want it to appear to be working at the beginning, so as to increase their credibility and position themselves for later conflict. see JPax Oct 26, 2015 11:29AM
9) there is a definite process to obtain access. see redacted Oct 17, 2015 03:12AM UTC
10) in this initial stage, the people that negotiated this deal will still be in position to resolve any issue. More importantly, most experts believe that this was a good deal for both sides.  see amashal Oct 25, 2015 08:55AM
11) the IAEA are not “gotcha” people. If they knew of a site or potential problem, they would have been upfront about addressing it with Iran. The IAEA has high standards to uphold, but they have also shown respect for Iran and sensitivity to the difficult situation within Iran. They have allowed flexibility to give Iran political cover at home. Maintaining this balance is crucial, so the IAEA would be very careful about using intelligence withheld by a government and then brought forward now that Iran has accepted the deal as a means to sabotage it.
see Scholar&Cat Oct 31, 2015 06:12AM Pivotal issues:
1) "Iran will be required to grant access to the IAEA to investigate suspicious sites or allegations of a covert enrichment facility, conversion facility, centrifuge production facility, or yellowcake production facility anywhere in the country". . . . is the IAEA going to ask to go to a military site before 1 July 2016. see Clinton Oct 5, 2015 05:29AM
2) it takes about 2 weeks for a minor issue to escalate to a dispute, so we may be able to see a problem brewing
3) closing date of this question Bottomline is I think that during this time frame every effort will be made to prevent something becoming an official dispute.  A weighted average (based on up votes) of forecasts made by the people quoted above is about 27, but I don't see either side allowing an issue to become a dispute after each has spent so much political capital to get a deal in place, so I'm going to go to 17.
The UN will look bad if not.
They are still trying to figure this whole deal out
Any possibility of renewing sanctions will prove too volatile for the economy.
Following Raisinville, and thanks to the admins for sending out an email alerting us to Raisinville's excellent commentary.
Iran will likely do its best to live up to the agreement at least not cause a confrontation with the inspecting body in the short run.
Reducing based on reasoning offered by @Raisinville, partially agree, will re-evaluate after IAEA report.

Taking a different approach: What are the odds that?
1) Iran has no hidden nuclear program, therefor there is nothing to inspect? - very high, based on current knowledge
2) What are the odds that Iran has nuclear sites that are hidden?  - very low, based on current knowledge
3) What are the odds that the IAEA will demand access to a sensitive military facility, that does not have a nuclear program.
    .......IAEA has not show a tendency to do this.
4) What are the odds that Iran has hidden facilities and the west knows about them and has't raised the subject yet? - This may be a Wildcard...but, I'll give it a 1 in 20 chance.
Reducing forecast, I may have focused on the possible gamesmanship of the dispute resolution process and not enough on the facts on the ground. The Joint Agreement also requests specific details regarding any claims for inspection, seems a low probability that any exist at this point.
Timing doesn't make this too likely, but still really possible.
IAEA first report is due early 2016. I believe there is significant investment and potential reward in the success in JPCOA  for all parties that at least initially there will great cooperation.
Assuming the implementation of the agreement happens in December and given that IAEA has already inspected everywhere they wanted there is very little chance that they want to inspect anywhere else.

There is some chance that one or more minor disputes about sites that will be resolved subsequently.  The Iranians are likely to test the efficacy of the agreement in order to discern its freedom of movement within its constraints.
We will see a dispute, and it will likely be about past military research. Iranians are loathe to let the outside world know how close they got, and how much stuxnet hurt them.
The Iranians will cooperate for the time being, they need to focus on Iraq and Syria.
Reducing from the 45% I predicted on 03 October to get nearer the consensus, as so far everything is moving smoothly. IAEA's report on 15 December looks like the next big milestone.
Iran will work to earn the sanctions relief.
No. Iran will first want to ensure all sanctions are lifted and all feel that Iran is complying before probing for weaknesses and testing the boundaries.
not enough time to consider non compliance and iran wants its money
The IAEA proved its accuracy to the world in Iraq. The Iranians understand and respect that world view, and will only make minor tests that can easily be denied or retracted.

Initial Thoughts: The chances of any of the parties will let access issues escalate to referral to the Join Commission by 1 July 2016 are low. All parties currently in position want it to appear to be working at the beginning, so as to increase their credibility and position themselves for later conflict. Thus, the IAEA will not push too hard and the Iranians will not resist within the next 8 months. I don't expect hardliner factions of the various parties to attempt to derail the agreement until later, with the first potential time frame for that as an October Surprise in the US election cycle.

Neither side wants a dispute at this early point in the life of the nuclear deal.     Iran needs to comply to obtain the lifting of sanctions, which the public are eagerly anticipating.    The current US administration are looking for a clean start to the deal and not an almost immediate dispute, especially in President Obama's final year.   Differences of opinion are more likely to be resolved fairly quickly offline by the original negotiators on both sides.

Iran has suffered due to the crippling sanctions much more than it is letting on.  Once the sanctions are lifted and the money starts flowing again, the reformers will have tasted a minor victory over the hard liners in Iran.  The government will not allow any disputes to jeopardize the newly found prosperity.  Although there is a small chance that the hard liners might perceive a loss of power or face and flex their muscles to cause problems.
I think there's a greater than 50% probablity that Iran will resist aceess to sites temporarily, just to test the parties involved in the treaty.  But I don't think it will be a major issue.
Supporters will argue to allow time for dispute resolution system to worked out in more detail.
Both countries conservatives want this to fail.  But Obama won't do anything to jeopardize this treaty while he is in office.

I'm operating on the assumption that there will be an attempt to inspect a major site before then. There is a high probability that Iran will be uncooperative once actually faced with inspections. My firm belief is that they (Iran) went through with this deal for noting else than to receive a large influx of cash to relieve the years of sanctions that in my opinion were just beginning to have their desired effects. In many deals, both parties have something to gain by following the rules but one of them has little to lose by breaking them. This is why a good used car is hard to find. But in this deal, both parties have a lot to gain by following the rules and a lot to lose by breaking them. I am certain that, in the two years they were talking, Kerry and Zarif talked about what their respective governments would say publicly and what that would really mean in practice. This is a fifteen-year deal. More than half the people now in the various governments will be gone by then. Only the paper and the processes it spawns survives. Kerry knew there were guys like Cotton and Cruz going into this thing. Zarif knew about his equivalents. Each of them had to satisfy the other that the agreement would survive those kinds of attacks, and part of that was teaching each other how to interpret extreme statements from legislators to their constituencies. I'm going to assume that all of this sound and fury was anticipated and is accounted for and that the fix is in.

Affirming forecast. I think the real question here is not whether there will be disputes; I'm sure there will be, and I'm sure Iran will be intransigent over inspections as other forecasters have pointed out. The question as posed is, "Will any disputes... be referred to the Joint Commission before 1 July 2016?" This is an entirely different matter. I think the west will take great pains to keep such a referral from happening, because 1) it can be interpreted as a failure of the west to negotiate the treaty properly (a controversy especially to be avoided in the U.S. during a presidential election) and 2) what if the Joint Commission rules against Iran on an issue, and Iran rejects the ruling, and does what it wants anyway? The sanctions against Iran are supposed to be completely eradicated by the end of 2015. Once the sanctions are rolled back, I think they will be extremely difficult to reimpose and I don't think "snapback" will work in any meaningful fashion. So my thinking is that by the middle of next year, Iran will pretty much be able to dig in its heels on any issue it chooses, and the west will have to mollify Iran. Thus in the event of any dispute, everyone will compromise rather than refer the dispute to the Joint Commission.

Not likely. The IAEA and Iran worked remarkably well together (and quickjly) on Parchin, so they have the basis for a dialogue. I think if there are issues, there will be a lot of talking before anything gets elevated to the level that may result in a referral to the Join Commission. down the road this may be possible, but I don't see it happening in the first half of 2016.

I don't see any issues with the "regular access to all of Iran’s nuclear facilities, including to Iran’s enrichment facility at Natanz and its former enrichment facility at Fordow, and including the use of the most up-to-date, modern monitoring technologies" - this they have agreed to. It is going to hinge on "Iran will be required to grant access to the IAEA to investigate suspicious sites or allegations of a covert enrichment facility, conversion facility, centrifuge production facility, or yellowcake production facility anywhere in the country"  The issue of requests to inspect military sites will be the problem given the statements made in the majles.  So my basis is : are the IAEA going to ask to go to a military site before 1 July 2016.  At this point I judge no, I assume they will be busy bees on the known sites and need to build a serious case of a suspicious site and generate enough momentum for allegations to follow before making such request.  In addition to the politics, they will need to be sure they are right, because they get it wrong on the first one and number 2 will be a problem.  Any news leaks creating a suspicion on a military complex with serious facts and figures rather than scare stories will make me adjust up.

Disputes over IAEA access are referred to the Joint Commission only if Iran and the IAEA are unable to reach resolution within 14 days of the IAEA making a request for access and providing the basis of the concern.  The Joint Commission has a week to make its determination on the matter, and Iran has a few days following that to provide access, if such is the finding of the JC.   Access requests can arise at any time, before or after implementation day.  While apparently some in Iran have said that they'll be able to get to implementation day early in 2016, the time estimates I've seen (for instance, https://news.riskadvisory.net/2015/16/iran-summary-of-nuclear-deal-timeline-and-sanctions-relief/) are roughly 6 months for Iran to complete the work it needs to do and 1-2 months for IAEA to say that it is ready. So - possible that the deal will get to implementation day prior to the end of this question (mid-Oct start of arrangements + 8 mos =mid-June). Expectation is that Iran will be trying to get the agreement implemented quickly.  A dispute could potentially delay implementation, so prior to implementation day Iran may be more likely to reach quick agreements with the IAEA.  But perhaps this expectation is incorrect, or incomplete, as some in Iran might not want the agreement implementation to go smoothly/quickly. Iran has blocked access before and it seems likely that an access dispute will at some point arise and reach the Joint Commission.  But, before July? For now, while I think a dispute will arise within a medium time-frame, maybe one won't by July.  If implementation day is reached more quickly than I think, need to increase probability here.  OTOH, if disputes arise and are quickly settled, that might be a stronger indication that a dispute won't be referred to the Joint Commission within the question time frame.

While we await the results of the investigations of the Parchim samples, it it important to note that the usual custody protocol was not maintained as the environmental samples were supplied to to the investigators and not directly obtained.  Accordingly, it is highly likely that the samples will show nothing of interest.  I would expect that the Iranians will make all reasonable attempts to be compliant, but against this attempt to show compliance and goodwill will be the IAEA inspector's needs to be demonstrating a certain agressiveness in terms of site inspections.  Thus, while there is a desire on the part of the Iranians to allow access to sites of interest, there is a non-zero probability that this balance may skew towards some dispute.  I would expect this probability to increase as the number of inspections completed increases, and the "low hanging fruit" is depleted.  Hence this initial forecast.

High forecast to start. Iran and the P5+1, have a nuclear agreement.  Before "Implementation Day" the IAEA will under take inspection of Iran's compliance with the agreement.  There are many opponents to the agreement both inside Iran and outside.   IAEA has authority for immediate access to sites listed as "declared nuclear sites".   This IFP is related to additional IAEA inspections at "undeclared" sites.  If IAEA has any suspicions about any location in Iran, including military facilities, there is a resolution process, here are the steps (summarized):
.....Day 0, IAEA issues a "Request for Clarification"...Provide Iran the request and basis for concerns.
.....Day 1 - 14, IAEA issues a written request, including relevant information, for access to the site if Iran's explanation does not meet it's requirements.  Within the 14 day window, the IAEA must either (with Iran) 1. agree on inspection proceedures, or 2. resolve the IAEA's concerns with alternative arraingements without inspections.
.....Day 15-21, If there is still no agreement, the IAEA and Iran will go before the "Joint Commission for Dispute Resolution". Members: P5+1, Iran, EU High Representative. Resolution needs 5 of 8 votes.
.....Day 22-24, implementation of any decision by the Joint Committee.  The "Iran Watch" link in the "more info" section, lists possible entities and suppliers that may be involved with Iranian nuclear programs. It lists about 769 entities and 224 suppliers.  Expect that there will be a lot of pressure on the IAEA to thouroughly investigate sites (possibly more, or more sensitive sites than are actually required), also expect a lot of pressure inside Iran by the military, etc., to not allow access to sensitive sites.  I'll forecast that the system will be tested both by the IAEA and Iran to see how the limits of this process will work.  I'll go 80% that they test the system.
Absolutely. These are all suspicious sites, but also high security.
Need to do more research, but seems unlikely that nothing would be referred to the joint commission over the year
IAEA and Iran will probably reach agreement on any disputes before it gets that far.
